content:
In mathlib we define ObjectProperty assuming that we are working in a category:

/-- A property of objects in a category `C` is a predicate `C → Prop`. -/
@[nolint unusedArguments]
abbrev ObjectProperty (C : Type u) [Category.{v} C] : Type u := C → Prop

I want to at least generalize this to CategoryStructs for use in bicategories. However, we are not even using a category struct here (even needing to use @[nolint unusedArguments]). When generalizing, should I just remove the Category/CategoryStruct assumption all together, or is it useful to keep it for some reason?
You may try to just remove the Category assumption here. If nothing bad happens (everything compiles, and !bench is happy), we may proceed...
In this case we should add to the docstring that this should only be used in a category theory context and not used as a synonym for Set.
out of curiosity, what are you planning to use this generalization for?

Edward van de Meent said:

out of curiosity, what are you planning to use this generalization for?

Firstly, more short-term, is to open the possiblity of defining full sub-bicategories using ObjectProperty (and then locally full sub-bicategories using a combination of object and morphism properties).

Later on, stacks will form a bicategory, and these will have a bunch of natural objectproperties (such as being Deligne-Mumford).

Or did you mean the generalization beyond CategoryStruct? If so, nothing :sweat_smile:

Christian Merten said:

In this case we should add to the docstring that this should only be used in a category theory context and not used as a synonym for Set.

Ah, so the Category assumption is basically a linter?
